content.title: Endograft Migration
content.description: Caudal movement of an endograft from its original fixation site, potentially leading to loss of seal, endoleak, and aneurysm repressurization.
content.definition: Endograft migration is defined as device movement >10mm from the original position or any movement leading to loss of seal zone. Most commonly occurs caudally (distally) and results from continued aortic neck dilation, inadequate fixation, or device fatigue. Can lead to Type I endoleak and late aneurysm rupture.

mechanisms: Neck dilation exceeds device seal zone
surveillance_detection: Measure proximal edge to lowest renal artery
Any Type Ia endoleak suggests migration/seal failure
management: Proximal extension cuff if neck adequate
Conversion to open repair if not amenable to endovascular
Close surveillance if stable and no endoleak

clinical_pearls: Migration is a late complication - may occur 5-10+ years post-EVAR
Hostile neck anatomy is the main risk factor
Type Ia endoleak is often first sign of migration
Lifetime surveillance is required after EVAR
Can be prevented by proper patient selection

content.statement: Endograft Migration is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Aaa that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Endograft Migration helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Endograft Migration include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Endograft Migration.
